dt: used to say that another person has no chance of succeeding at something

dt.t: "He thinks he can beat you." "{it}I'd (just) like to see him try{/it}!"

shortdef: —used to say that another person has no chance of succeeding at something

dt: {bc}a usually raised structure or place on which sacrifices are offered or incense is burned in worship
often used figuratively to describe a thing given great or undue precedence or value especially at the cost of something else

dt.t: sacrificed his family life on the {wi}altar{/wi} of career advancement

dt: {bc}a tablelike construction used in the Christian church in celebrating the Eucharist
{bc}a table or place which serves as a center of worship or ritual
often used with {it}the{/it} to refer to the act of getting married

dt.t: They are destined for the {wi}altar{/wi}.
She {phrase}left him at the altar{/phrase}. {gloss}=she decided at the last minute not to go through with her planned marriage to him{/gloss}

et: Middle English {it}alter{/it}, from Old English {it}altar{/it}, from Latin {it}altare{/it}; probably akin to Latin {it}adolēre{/it} to burn up
shortdef: a usually raised structure or place on which sacrifices are offered or incense is burned in worship —often used figuratively to describe a thing given great or undue precedence or value especially at the cost of something else

dt: {bc}a cutting tool that consists of a heavy edged head fixed to a handle with the edge parallel to the handle and that is used especially for felling trees and chopping and splitting wood

dt.t: Employees with poor evaluations {phrase}got the axe{/phrase}.

dt: {bc}abrupt elimination or severe reduction of something

dt.t: Unlimited expense accounts, signing bonuses, and office plants—all are {phrase}getting the ax{/phrase} {gloss}=being cut or eliminated{/gloss} thanks to corporate cost-cutting measures.
No party was brave enough to offend its supporters by {phrase}taking an axe to{/phrase} {gloss}=severely reducing{/gloss} expenditure.

dt: {bc}any of several musical instruments (such as a guitar or a saxophone)

dt.t: claims that he has no {it}axe to grind{/it} in criticizing the proposed law

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}æcs{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}ackus{/it} ax, Latin {it}ascia{/it}, Greek {it}axinē{/it}
shortdef: a cutting tool that consists of a heavy edged head fixed to a handle with the edge parallel to the handle and that is used especially for felling trees and chopping and splitting wood
a hammer with a sharp edge for dressing or spalling stone

dt: {bc}a hollow metallic device that gives off a reverberating sound when struck
{bc}the sounding of a bell as a signal
{bc}a stroke of a bell (as on shipboard) to indicate the time
{bc}a half hour period of a watch on shipboard indicated by the strokes of a bell {dx}see {dxt|Ship's Bells Table|bell|table}{/dx}
{bc}something having the form of a bell: such as
{bc}a bell-shaped organ or part (such as the {d_link|dewlap|dewlap} of a moose)
{bc}the bell- or saucer-shaped, largely gelatinous structure that forms the main part of the body of most jellyfish {bc}{sx|umbrella:1||3}
{bc}the part of the capital of a column between the abacus and neck molding
{bc}the flared end of a wind instrument
{bc}the open mouth of a {d_link|nozzle|nozzle} (such as of the exhaust of a jet engine)

dt.t: The heating was so intense … that the gas went rushing out the tail of the engine at 30,000 feet per second, or twice the speed at which exhaust leaves the {wi}bell{/wi} of a conventional engine.

dt: {bc}a percussion instrument consisting of metal bars or tubes that when struck give out tones resembling {a_link|bells}
{bc}to be hit on the head {bc}to suffer a concussion

dt.t: He had {wi}his bell rung{/wi} on a blitz, and a short time later he was taken to Divine Providence Hospital.
Maybe Cowell can {wi}give him a bell{/wi} towards the end of his marathon broadcast—that would certainly wake him up.

et: Middle English {it}belle{/it}, from Old English; perhaps akin to Old English {it}bellan{/it} to roar {ma}{mat|bellow|}{/ma}
shortdef: a hollow metallic device that gives off a reverberating sound when struck
doorbell
the sounding of a bell as a signal

{wi}bites{/wi} down on the part

dt: {bc}to respond so as to be caught (as by a trick)

dt: {bc}to undertake more than one can handle

{bc}to enter with resignation upon a difficult or distressing course of action

dros.drp: bite the hand that feeds one

et: Middle English {it}biten,{/it} going back to Old English {it}bītan,{/it} going back to Germanic {it}*bītan-{/it} (whence Old Saxon {it}bītan{/it} "to bite, cut into," Old High German {it}bīzan,{/it} Old Norse {it}bíta,{/it} Gothic {it}beitan{/it}), going back to Indo-European {it}*b{sup}h{/sup}ei̯d-{/it} "split," whence also Latin {it}findere{/it} "to split, cleave, divide" (from a derivative {it}*b{sup}h{/sup}i-n-d-{/it}), Sanskrit {it}abhet{/it} "has split," {it}bhinátti{/it} "(s/he) splits" and perhaps Greek {it}pheídomai, pheídesthai{/it} "to spare, save, refrain from"
shortdef: to seize especially with teeth or jaws so as to enter, grip, or wound
to wound, pierce, or sting especially with a fang or a proboscis
to cut or pierce with or as if with an edged weapon

{bc}to criticize, blame, or punish (someone in a vulnerable position) especially in order to avoid blame or gain an advantage

dt.t: … we will not {wi}throw{/wi} any student {wi}under the bus{/wi} for instant restoration of our image or our reputation.
But he went out of his way to make clear that this one wasn't really on him. The problem lay with underlings, whom he quickly {wi}threw under the bus{/wi}.

shortdef: a large motor vehicle designed to carry passengers usually along a fixed route according to a schedule
automobile
a small hand truck

dt: {bc}a piece of glowing carbon or charred wood {bc}{sx|ember||}

{bc}a black or brownish-black solid combustible substance formed by the partial decomposition of vegetable matter without free access of air and under the influence of moisture and often increased pressure and temperature that is widely used as a natural fuel
{bc}pieces or a quantity of the fuel broken up for burning

dt.t: The government was then {it}raked over the coals{/it} for refusing to send out information about the candidates.

The Headmaster was angry. So angry, indeed, that he did what in a more lucid interval he would not have done. He {it}hauled{/it} a senior {it}over the coals{/it} in the hearing of a number of juniors …

et: Middle English {it}col{/it}, from Old English; akin to Old High German & Old Norse {it}kol{/it} burning ember, Middle Irish {it}gúal{/it} coal
shortdef: a piece of glowing carbon or charred wood : ember
charcoal

a black or brownish-black solid combustible substance formed by the partial decomposition of vegetable matter without free access of air and under the influence of moisture and often increased pressure and temperature that is widely used as a natural fuel

dt: used as a euphemism for {d_link|fuck|fuck:1} in various senses of the word

dt.t: You don't {phrase}eff with{/phrase} {gloss}=mess with{/gloss} the Tupac legacy. You just don't.
A guy who likes you a bit more than you like him generally … doesn't {wi}eff with{/wi} your mind.
She told them to {phrase}eff off{/phrase} {gloss}=scram{/gloss}.
… he sees this age of mass travel, mass entertainment and mass culture as the best of all possible ages. Anyone who disagrees, he snarls, had better {wi}eff off{/wi} now.

Toronto city council huffed and puffed, the Ford brothers blustered and bullied, the mayor even admitted to buying drugs while in office, and there were renewed apologies: "There is nothing else to say, guys. I really {phrase}effed up{/phrase} {gloss}=messed up{/gloss}."
They threatened to {wi}eff{/wi} him {wi}up{/wi} if he didn't cooperate.
He says something at the end of the movie that {phrase}effed{/phrase} me {phrase}up{/phrase} {gloss}=upset or shocked me{/gloss}.

et: spelling variant of {et_link|ef|ef}, representing the initial letter of {et_link|fuck:1|fuck:1}
shortdef: —used as a euphemism for fuck in various senses of the word
